subject: RE: [junit] Message texts
msgSnippet: Yes, I was just trying to write the most simple example. I guess, what I m asking is, since you write a positive assert, should you write a positive
messageBody:
Yes, I was just trying to write the most simple example.

I guess, what I'm asking is, since you write a "positive" assert, should you
write a "positive" message? Or a "negative" message in case the assert
failed.

So I have been writing
assertTrue("The filename should end in .log",
filename.endsWith(".log"));
assuming the assert doesn't fail.

Another responder wrote "this looks like a comment", and yes, it does, but
is that a bad thing?

OTOH, you would only see the message in junit output (wherever that may be)
when the assert really did fail --
so maybe it SHOULD be a 'negative' message, e.g.
assertTrue("The filename doesn't end in .log?",
filename.endsWith(".log"));
This is what JB was saying.

Thanks
--DP

-----Original Message-----
From: Chris Wright [mailto:subscriptions@...]
Sent: Wednesday, July 21, 2004 2:11 PM
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Subject: RE: [junit] Message texts


-----Original Message-----
From: David Plass [mailto:dplass@...]
Sent: Wednesday, July 21, 2004 6:56 PM
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Subject: RE: [junit] Message texts


>So you'd write
assertTrue("someBoolean is not true!", someBoolean);

>Or as another example
assertEquals("The answer isn't the same!", expected, actual);



Probably best to replace 'someBoolean' or 'answer' with the idea of what you
are testing, as in 'The surname did not match the one I was looking for'.
Or, 'The ages of the clients are not equal'.

I am sure you probably have quite a few booleans in your code that you are
checking, but JB's suggestion was to put something meaningful that you can
come back and recognise when debugging later on. Having just 'someBoolean'
does not really tell you much does it...
Having an individual description will let you know exactly where the failure
occurred, but creates just that little bit of overhead when creating the
assertion itself.


Regards

CW
